title: Euro 2020 qualifying: Holland and Northern Ireland pay tribute to the late Fernando Ricksen
text:
Northern Ireland and Holland paid tribute to the late great Fernando Ricksen before their Euro 2020 qualifier on Thursday night.

The two teams took part in a minute's applause to honour the memory of the Rangers legend who passed away last month following a six-year battle with motor neurone disease.

The moving tribute was met with chants of 'there's only one Fernando Ricksen' from the crowd before the game kicked off at Feyenoord's De Kuip stadium.

Scroll down for video

Holland and Northern Ireland players pay tribute to Fernando Ricksen who died last month

(Left to right) Daley Blind, Memphis Depay and Ryan Babel take part in the minute's applause

Both sets of supporters also chanted 'there's only one Fernando Ricksen' during the tribute

"One Fernando Ricksen..." 💙



A wonderful tribute to former the Rangers legend and Dutch international before Netherlands v Northern Ireland



📺 Watch the #Euro2020 qualifier live now on Sky Sports pic.twitter.com/t3r9zIDfAh — Sky Sports Football (@SkyFootball) October 10, 2019

A black and white image of Ricksen adorned the screens inside the ground along with along with 'Fernando Ricksen 1976-2019'.

The tribute comes just a few weeks after Ricksen was laid to rest following his funeral in Glasgow.

Holland went on to win the game as Ronald Koeman's side came from behind to beat their Group C opponents.

The Northern Ireland fans applauded Ricksen before their team's Euro 2020 qualifier

The Rangers legend bravely battled motor neurone disease for six years

Michael O'Neill's men took a shock lead through substitute Josh Magennis in the 75th minute before Memphis Depay levelled the scores.

Then, in injury time, Frenkie de Jong broke the visitors' hearts with a late strike before Depay added to his tally with a third goal for Holland.

Despite the defeat, Norther Ireland sit level on points with Germany and Holland at the top of the table.
description: The two teams took part in a minute's applause to honour the memory of the Rangers legend who passed away last month following a six-year battle with motor neurone disease.
